content.rendered:
I previously talked about one of my favorite features, CMS Connect, I was given an amazing opportunity, had the chance to present with Kyle O’Brien, a rockstar on the Community Cloud team, at Connections (#CNX18) on just that on my birthday this year.

So what I want to tell you about is the fact that since my last post, there have been some updates to the CMS Connect functionality.  First, the setup itself has changed, it’s become more streamlined for the JSON connection, making the ability to connect to your blog, easier.  Also, you now have the option to use named credentials.

  • Named Credentials
  • JSON Config Updates
    • Step 1: CORS
    • Step 2: The Connection
      • BASICS
      • JSON
        • Type: Content Item
        • Type: Content List
    • Step 3: Blog Post List Page
    • Step 4: Blog Post page
    • Step 5: Check out Your Components
    • OPTIONAL Step 6: Change the Blog Post Page Name
  • Conclusion

Named Credentials

What is a named credential? Well let’s break it down.  So Named Credentials, Named Creds if you wanna be all cool (ok I totally made that up, but it sounds cool right?) anyway, they are kinda like those Remote Site Settings in the Security area, they help you access a site that is outside of Salesforce.  The difference is Named Creds are used to connect you to a URL (site) that requires authentication. You can use either a username and password style authentication or you can use Oauth.

If you’re connecting to your blog where you publicly post, you wouldn’t use a named credential, but if you have, let’s say, an external LMS (Learning Management System) that has content, and you grant your Community users have access to that but you want to avoid having to make them login into the LMS and the community skipping back and forth, you could setup a connection with CMS connect using authentication, and display the data to your users.

You could take it a step further.  Let’s say only some of your users have access to this data that requires authentication.  You could even get really fancy, use some dynamic components, that state show component to users where XYZ criteria = true, to display the CMS Connect component to users that are flagged with access.  Pretty snazzy huh?  And to think, all out of the box!

JSON Config Updates

Step 1: CORS

CMS Connect uses Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) to access external content. Make sure to add Community Host to the list of trusted hosts in the CORS header in your CMS system.

This means that you need to setup your blog in the CORS section in Setup.

  1. To do this go to Setup – Security Controls – CORS or you can go to Setup and search for CORS in the quick find.
  2. Click the New button
  3. Enter your blog domain. You can either enter the domain itself or use a wildcard if you have a subdomain.

Step 2: The Connection

This functionality is for Communities and requires an enabled Community. Once you have a community created, you will be able to create the connection between your WordPress site and your Community.

  1. Access the Community you want to connect to WordPress.
  2. In the Community Workspace, select CMS Connect.
  3. Once in the CMS Connect settings, click bright blue “New” button in the upper right. This is where you will enter the information for your connection.
  4. The Connection Information:

BASICS

  • Name: Enter a name that will make this Connection easy to recognize, I used “WordPress”
  • CMS Source: WordPress
  • Connection type: Public
  • Server URL: https://public-api.wordpress.com

JSON

  • In the JSON section we want to setup 2 paths
  • Name your content type for your blog feed, I used “Posts”
Type: Content Item
  • Name: Enter the name for your individual blog posts, I used “Post”
  • Path: modify this text, replacing where I have ‘meighanrockssf’ with your blog URL:
    • Custom Domain: rest/v1.1/sites/meighanrockssf.com/posts/{component}
    • WordPress.com: rest/v1.1/sites/meighanrockssf.wordpress.com/posts/{component}
    • **NEW** ID path: ID
    • **NEW** Title Path: title
Type: Content List
  • Name: Enter the name for your blog post list, I used “Feed”
  • Path: again, modify this text, replacing where I have ‘meighanrockssf’ with your blog URL:
    • Custom Domain: rest/v1.1/sites/meighanrockssf.com/posts?number={itemsPerPage}&page={pageNumber}
    • WordPress.com: rest/v1.1/sites/meighanrockssf.wordpress.com/posts?number={itemsPerPage}&page={pageNumber}
    • **NEW** Node Path: posts

Step 3: Blog Post List Page

Next up we need to create the page that will hold the list of blog posts. To do this we need to create another page in the Community Builder

  • Create a custom Community page. Select whatever layout you prefer to display your blog post list.
  • On the Community page, add the CMS Connect (JSON) component in the Content area.
    • JSON Content: Feed
    • Component Path: LEAVE THIS BLANK
    • Content List Node Path: @post
    • Items Per Page: This is totally up to you, but I go with 9 as the default
    • Columns: Again, totally up to you, but I go with 3 as the default
    • Content List Layout: Grid
    • Detail: @detail
    • Author @name/author
    • Date: @date
    • Content: @content
    • Featured Image: @featured_image
    • Enter the Properties information for the CMS Connection we created:CMS Source: Select the CMS Connection we just created
    • Link Text: Read More

Step 4: Blog Post page

The next step is to update the page in the Community that was auto-created for your blog

posts to display on. We only need to make one, and the component will dynamically show the content based on the ID added at the end of the URL.

  1. Go to the Community Builder.
  2. Create a custom Community page. Select whatever layout you prefer to display your blog post detail.
  3. On the Community page, add the CMS Connect (JSON) component in the Content area.
  4. Enter the Properties information for the CMS Connection we created:CMS Source: Select the CMS Connection we just created
    • JSON Content: post
    • Component Path: {!recordId}
    • Content Item Layout: Detail
    • Detail: @detail
    • Author @author/name
    • Date: @date
    • Content: @content
    • Featured Image: @featured_image

Step 5: Check out Your Components

So, if you look at your blog list page now, you’ll notice that your blog posts from your WordPress site are all listed in a pretty Grid of Cards!

Fantastic! Now, we can’t click our Read More links in the builder, so we will want to click the Preview button in the upper right to check if our Post Detail page works. I like to click the pop into a new tab button too, just so it’s easier to see everything and the URL updates.

Here we have our beautiful list of posts on the Blog page. You can see the URL at the top, and the Read More link on each post. I click the Read More link on the Join Me When I Present at the World Tour post and….

BOOM!

The Read More link directs us to the Post Detail page we created, and you can see the Post ID has been appended to the end of the URL, and the page displays your blog post. Like magic, you have your WordPress content showing in your community, no need to maintain both, your data will update in Salesforce when you add new posts in WordPress.

OPTIONAL Step 6: Change the Blog Post Page Name

The Blog Post page was auto created for you, you can change the name of this page to be anything you want.

  • In the builder, click the Gear at the top of the page where you have your pages listed
  • Then click the three dots next to the page that was auto created
  • You’ll see at the bottom where you can change the Base URL, click there to update the page name and it’s URL

Conclusion

There you go! You’re now ready to use the CMS Connect Updates! Can’t wait to see what comes next…

excerpt.rendered: My experience at Connections 18 and updates to CMS Connect for your Lightning Community, learn all about it here!

jetpack-related-posts.title: CMS Connect for WordPress
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: So you want to connect your WordPress site to your Community? Here's how it's done with CMS Connect.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Native CMS
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Out of the box you you have 3 types of CMS, native CMS is one of those 3. Learn all about it from how to create articles, use cases, and why use Native CMS.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce CRM CMS
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: We've talked CMS Connect, Native CMS, now hear all about Salesforce CRM CMS and the wins you get using it in your community!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Dreamforce 18 – The Thursday of Presentations
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: This Dreamforce was c-razy!! Not only was it my first Dreamforce as an MVP, but it was also the Dreamforce of back to back action for me. Here's a bit about my #DF18 adventure...

jetpack-related-posts.title: TLS 1.0 Disablement & You
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: TLS 1.0 has been disabled in this organization. Please use TLS 1.1 or higher when connecting to Salesforce using https If you are seeing this error, take a deep breath. There is no need to panic, this is not a showstopper.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce #OhanaSlack
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Salesforce #OhanaSlack is a Slack Workspace that's available to connect with theSalesforce community and get real time help 24/7.
